=== Game Rules ===
This is vgdl rule file:
BasicGame square_size=32
    SpriteSet
        background > Immovable img=oryx/space1 hidden=True
        base    > Immovable    color=WHITE img=oryx/planet
        avatar  > FlakAvatar   stype=sam img=oryx/spaceship1
        missile > Missile
            sam  > orientation=UP    color=BLUE singleton=True img=oryx/bullet1
            bomb > orientation=DOWN  color=RED  speed=0.5 img=oryx/bullet2
        alien   > Bomber       stype=bomb   prob=0.01  cooldown=3 speed=0.8
            alienGreen > img=oryx/alien3
            alienBlue > img=oryx/alien1
        portal  > invisible=True hidden=True
        	portalSlow  > SpawnPoint   stype=alienBlue  cooldown=16   total=20 img=portal
        	portalFast  > SpawnPoint   stype=alienGreen  cooldown=12   total=20 img=portal

    LevelMapping
        . > background
        0 > background base
        1 > background portalSlow
        2 > background portalFast
        A > background avatar

    TerminationSet
        SpriteCounter      stype=avatar               limit=0 win=False
        MultiSpriteCounter stype1=portal stype2=alien limit=0 win=True

    InteractionSet
        avatar  EOS  > stepBack
        alien   EOS  > turnAround
        missile EOS  > killSprite

        base bomb > killBoth
        base sam > killBoth scoreChange=1

        base   alien > killSprite
        avatar alien > killSprite scoreChange=-1
        avatar bomb  > killSprite scoreChange=-1
        alien  sam   > killSprite scoreChange=2

This is vgdl rule in natural language:
Below is an analysis of the game:

1. Game Genre and Theme
 • It’s a classic, arcade‐style space shooter. You control a spaceship (the “avatar”) in outer space, facing off against waves of alien enemies.
 • The visuals include a colorful spaceship, planets (the “base”), alien ships, and bombs—giving it a retro, arcade/sci‐fi atmosphere.

2. Game Mechanics
 • You control a spaceship avatar that can fire a projectile called “sam” (a blue bullet). There’s also a missile sprite defined, though most combat seems to revolve around the “sam” projectile.
 • The aliens, which come in different types (alienBlue and alienGreen), are launched by invisible portal spawn points (“portalSlow” and “portalFast”). They slowly move across the screen and drop bombs with a low probability.
 • The base is an immovable element (shown as a white planet). It plays a unique role: it can interact with both your bullet and enemy projectiles.
 • When sprites reach the screen’s edge (EOS), they either “stepBack” (the avatar) or “turnAround” (the aliens), so movement is limited within the play area.
 • Enemies drop bombs that travel downward; these bombs can harm your spaceship or your base if they collide.

3. Objectives and Win/Loss Conditions
 • The primary goal is to eliminate all enemy forces. The win condition is met when both all portals (responsible for spawning aliens) and any remaining aliens are cleared from the game.
 • Your own survival is crucial. The loss condition kicks in if your avatar is destroyed (the SpriteCounter for stype=avatar reaches 0).

4. Collision Interactions and Scoring
 • The “sam” bullet is very important:
  – When it hits an alien (“alien sam”), it not only destroys the enemy but adds a positive score (+2 points).
  – However, if it accidentally hits your base (“base sam”), both the bullet and base are destroyed, though you gain a smaller bonus (+1 point). That suggests careful aiming is needed.
 • Collisions involving the avatar have mixed results:
  – If your avatar runs into an alien, the alien is destroyed but you lose points (–1 point).
  – Colliding with enemy bombs similarly destroys the bomb but penalizes your score (–1 point).
 • The base interacts with bombs very unforgivingly: a bomb hitting the base (“base bomb”) destroys both it and the bomb. Meanwhile, if an alien touches the base, the alien is simply removed (“base alien”) without a penalty, perhaps implying the base can serve as a last‐line defense.

5. Overall Strategy Suggestions
 • Keep Your Distance and Aim Precisely:
  – Steer your spaceship carefully so you don’t accidentally run into an alien or let a falling bomb hit you or your base. Avoid direct collisions that cost you points.
  – Use the blue “sam” projectile to target aliens. Given that hitting an alien provides a higher score bonus (+2) compared to accidentally hitting your base (+1), hone your aim.
 • Monitor Enemy Spawn Points:
  – Notice where the invisible portals are located; these spawn the alien ships. Prioritize eliminating the waves spawned by these portals to meet the win condition.
 • Protect Your Base:
  – Your base seems to play a twofold role: it can eliminate aliens on contact, but it’s vulnerable to enemy bombs. Try to keep enemy bombs away and, if possible, let the base’s “killBoth” mechanism (when hit by a bomb) work only when it won’t jeopardize your overall defense.
 • Balance Aggression With Caution:
  – While you can destroy enemies by colliding with them (avatar alien) or even enemy bombs (avatar bomb), these moves cost you points. It’s best to rely on shooting them with “sam.”
  – Position yourself such that the aliens are forced to change direction at the screen edge (alien EOS turning around), buying you extra time to shoot them.
 • Overall, keep control of the battlefield:
  – Focus on reducing the number of enemy aliens and ensuring no new ones spawn from the portals.
  – Maintain your avatar’s health by avoiding risky collisions, and use the environment (including the base) wisely to help thin enemy numbers.
  – A steady, careful approach that prioritizes accurate shooting over reckless maneuvers is likely to yield the best results.

In summary, this space shooter challenges you to manage a few moving parts—the spaceship, its bullet “sam,” enemy aliens that spawn from hidden portals, bombs dropped by enemy vessels, and a base that both helps and hinders you. Your best overall strategy is to aim carefully, avoid direct collisions, and methodically clear the enemies and their spawn points while protecting your avatar.

You are an intelligent player playing a video game, and you have a friend provide you strategy. Interpret the state, rule, strategy and act accordingly. Notice that your avatar position is one of the most important information, if the position doesn't change from the last state, you need to analyze the state and make a different action from the last time.

=== Available Actions ===
0: ACTION_NIL
1: ACTION_USE
2: ACTION_LEFT
3: ACTION_RIGHT

=== High Level Plan === 


**avatar strategy: Align with sam to ensure efficient use of its projectile power by batch-processing interactions against alienBlue and bomb threats before entering critical enemy corridors** without **Alert**Evaluation: BAD
Feedback: Moving right increases the horizontal distance from sam, as sam is positioned to the left of the avatar. This move does not reduce the overall separation and thus fails to advance toward the objective.

Please understand the rule and the interaction set first, then locate the item, finally choose a meaningful action towards the win and respond in the format: ``` Action:<action number> ```. Include one sentence of feedback on the action and your expectation to see if it aligns with the strategy. Notice, Action 0 will not reasult in any change in this game environment, and you may need to understand the level layout first to play the game.
